title: Erdős Problem #179: Arithmetic Progression Supersaturation
description: For integers 1 ≤ k < ℓ, define F_k(N, ℓ) as the minimum number such that every set A ⊆ ℕ of size N containing at least F_k(N, ℓ) many k-term APs must contain an ℓ-term AP. Questions: Is F₃(N, 4) = o(N²)? Is lim log F₃(N, ℓ) / log N = 2 for all ℓ > 3? Answer: YES to both.

meta.author: Fox-Pohoata (2020), Leng-Sah-Sawhney (2024)

originalContributions: Formal definition of the supersaturation function F_k(N, ℓ)
Axiomatization of Fox-Pohoata and Leng-Sah-Sawhney bounds
Connection to Szemerédi's theorem and Roth's theorem
Formalization of Erdős's two specific questions

overview.historicalContext: Erdős posed this problem about arithmetic progression supersaturation, asking: if a set has 'too many' k-term APs, must it contain a longer ℓ-term AP? This connects to the broader theme of density and structure in combinatorics. Fox and Pohoata resolved both questions in 2020, showing F_k(N, ℓ) = N^{2-o(1)}. Leng, Sah, and Sawhney improved the bounds in 2024 using advances in Szemerédi's theorem.
overview.problemStatement:
Let 1 ≤ k < ℓ be integers. Define F_k(N, ℓ) as the minimum number such that every set A ⊆ ℕ of size N containing at least F_k(N, ℓ) many k-term arithmetic progressions must contain an ℓ-term AP.

Erdős asked two questions:
1. Is F₃(N, 4) = o(N²)?
2. For every ℓ > 3, is lim_{N→∞} log F₃(N, ℓ) / log N = 2?

The answer to both is YES.
overview.proofStrategy:
The formalization:

1. Defines arithmetic progressions and the counting function
2. Defines the supersaturation function F_k(N, ℓ)
3. States Erdős's two questions formally
4. Axiomatizes Fox-Pohoata's bound: F_k(N, ℓ) ≤ N² / (log log N)^C
5. Axiomatizes Leng-Sah-Sawhney's improvement: F_k(N, ℓ) ≤ N² / exp((log log N)^c)
6. Proves both questions are resolved by these results
7. Connects to Szemerédi's theorem and Roth's theorem
keyInsights: The supersaturation function F_k(N, ℓ) captures when having many short APs forces long APs
F_k(N, ℓ) = N^{2-o(1)} means the exponent is 2 but with a slowly decaying correction
Bounds on F_k relate directly to bounds on r_ℓ(N), the Szemerédi function
The 2024 improvements use breakthrough bounds for Szemerédi's theorem

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #179 asks about the supersaturation function F_k(N, ℓ): how many k-term APs force an ℓ-term AP? Both of Erdős's questions have affirmative answers: F₃(N, 4) = o(N²) and the limiting exponent is 2. This was proved by Fox-Pohoata in 2020, with improvements by Leng-Sah-Sawhney in 2024.
conclusion.implications:
The supersaturation phenomenon connects to:

1. Szemerédi's theorem on arithmetic progressions in dense sets
2. Bounds on r_ℓ(N), the maximum size of AP-free sets
3. The broader theory of extremal combinatorics
4. Ramsey-type questions about forcing structure
openQuestions: Optimal constants C_ℓ and c_ℓ in the bounds
